However, because this error is likely long-term dependent, and the probability distributions for its components are not necessarily normal, finding and justifying a proper parametric model for it is non-trivial. To deal with this conundrum, we adopt an approach inspired by prior work [ 37]. We postulate that model error can be derived from inter-model trend differences. The reasoning for this implementation is as follows. Imagine a particular trend submodel M

directly from the differences between each model’s trend and the next-closest model trend (see [ 9] for details). We acknowledge that this parameterization is simplified; model error is an emergent research topic [ 37]. We thus hope this work can galvanize more research on parametrizing model error.
